content: until suitable automation or management of the SMF data disks is established. 76 Virtualization Cookbook: Vol 1: IBM z/VM 7.2 It might be tempting to use IBMVM1 because it is supplied to log into the system, rather than using it as a model for creating user IDs for system administration staff and correctly setting up surrogate logon. The use of IBMVM1 for anything other than a modeling template represents a significant security exposure for the following reasons:  The password for IBMVM1 is treated as another shared ID password (for example, as the MAINT password was treated in the past)  Through surrogate logon, IBMVM1 gives access to many IDs on the system. Therefore, a poorly-secured IBMVM1 password can give access to almost every administration ID that is on a z/VM system. After your local system administrator IDs are defined and thoroughly tested to ensure that they function as expected, we recommend that the IBMVM1 ID is disabled by setting the password to NOLOG, as described
